list_definition.definition: to force (something out of something) gradually and with difficulty

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He winkled the shell out from the rock
He tried to winkle some information out of her.

list_definition.definition: (also periwinkleˈperi-) a type of small shellfish, shaped like a small snail, eaten as food.

list_ex_of_english: Any new ceasefire must also mean an end to winkling people out from their homes and farms, and an end to the boycotts.
That does not sound like winkling out to me; it sounds like being on the front foot.
The new audit commission will winkle out many more problems that the direct labour organisations have caused.
There is nothing particularly secret about the information, although it takes some winkling out.
If the amendments were intended to be probing amendments, they have perhaps winkled out a pearl or two.
The parties, however active, are unlikely to winkle out all such people.
They use harassment to winkle out the sitting tenant and obtain vacant possession.
We were asking for positive discrimination in favour of shoes which were medically sound, not in favour of the wedge heels and the winkle-pickers.
